questions.clue: This country has won the most FIFA World Cup titles, with a total of 5 victories.
The 2022 FIFA World Cup was held in this Middle Eastern country, marking the first time it was hosted there.
This player, known as 'El Fenómeno,' scored 8 goals in the 2002 World Cup, leading his team to victory.
In 1950, this country won the World Cup by defeating Brazil 2-1 in a match known as the 'Maracanazo.'
As of 2022, this goalkeeper holds the record for the most clean sheets in World Cup history, with 10.
This Greek god, known for his winged sandals, was the messenger of the gods and could be compared to a speedy soccer player on the field.
According to Roman mythology, this two-faced god could look both forward and backward, much like a soccer coach analyzing past and future matches.
This Norse god, often associated with thunder and lightning, wields a mighty hammer, as a soccer player might wield a powerful strike.
In Hindu mythology, this monkey god is known for his incredible strength and loyalty, akin to a midfielder who tirelessly supports both defense and attack.
This hero of the ancient Greek epic, the Iliad, was invulnerable in all but one spot, similar to a soccer team with a single weak point in its defense.
Just like predicting the winner of a World Cup, this principle states you can't know both the position and momentum of a particle with absolute certainty.
These fundamental particles, similar to the way soccer teams are the building blocks of a World Cup, are the building blocks of protons and neutrons.
This famous thought experiment involving a cat in a box is an analogy for the superposition principle in quantum mechanics.

Similar to how a soccer game is unpredictable, this concept describes how particles can be connected in such a way that the state of one instantly influences the state of another, no matter the distance.
This phenomenon, which shares its name with an offside trap in soccer, allows particles to pass through a barrier that they seemingly shouldn't be able to pass.
Known for its pizza and pasta, this Italian city is also the capital of the country that won the 2006 FIFA World Cup.
Famous for its croissants and haute cuisine, this city is the capital of the country that won the 1998 FIFA World Cup.
Known for its sushi and ramen, this city is the capital of the country that co-hosted the 2002 FIFA World Cup.
This South American city is renowned for its asado and is the capital of the country with two FIFA World Cup wins in 1978 and 1986.
A hub for borscht and pelmeni, this city is the capital of the country that hosted the 2018 FIFA World Cup.
This epic poem by Homer tells the story of Odysseus' 10-year journey home after the Trojan War, which inspired a 2006 World Cup ad campaign.
In this 1847 novel by Charlotte Brontë, the mysterious Mr. Rochester hosts lavish parties, akin to a soccer team hosting a World Cup gala.
This Russian novel, considered one of the greatest, opens with a family gathering that rivals any World Cup opening ceremony.
In this novel by Gabriel García Márquez, the Buendía family saga unfolds with drama and passion, much like the intense matches of the 1986 World Cup.
This 1922 work by James Joyce parallels Homer's epic and is set on a single day in Dublin, just as a World Cup final is a single, defining moment.

final.clue: This country's national soccer team, known as 'La Albiceleste', has won the FIFA World Cup three times, with their most recent victory in 2022.
